subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] Utter/Ado
msgSnippet: Read got rid of the two forms of utter present in Shavian after testing the alphabet.  I assume he found it an unnecessary complication which QS could avoid.
messageBody:
Read got rid of the two forms of "utter" present in Shavian after testing the alphabet.  I assume he found it an unnecessary complication which QS could avoid.  The alternative form of "utter" is useful for writing.  Attempting to elevate it to a separate letter seems to be taking a step backward to me. 

First, Read already decided against the need for the separate letter.  Do we have any evidence that was a mistake?  Secondly, the alternative form serves a very useful purpose for hand written QS, and changing that by making it a new letter ruins that use.  I don't think the BIC or Papermate pen companies are in danger of going out of business anytime soon, and for the foreseeable future people will continue to write.  Therefore, anything which negatively impacts the use of QS for handwritten communication would not get my vote.  And finally, while the use of junior QS for typewritten documents works fine, and Paul's new font is excellent, I still feel the unique beauty of QS is best expressed in the senior form with full use of the half-letters and ligatures.  I am still waiting and hoping for a font that will allow us to produce on our computers what we can see in our handwritten QS.

Paige

Paul Tremblay wrote:

Ted Larson Freeman wrote:
> >
> I think it's best to continue to use 'original utter' in the ligature
> of #36+#25. This does lead naturally to the question (already under
> discussion) of whether this ligature should be considered a letter in
> it's own right. That question is complicated by the fact that there
> are other ligatures such as #33+#25 which would also be candidates for
> letter-hood. This is a bit of a quandry since it seems to me that the
> larger the alphabet, the more intimidating it is for beginners.
>
> I've updated this document to reflect these ideas:
> http://staff. washington. edu/freeman/ qs/qs_proposal2. pdf
> <http://staff. washington. edu/freeman/ qs/qs_proposal2. pdf>
>
> (Comments on the choices of ligatures to include in a new font, and
> their names and keyboard assignments are welcome!)
>

Hi Ted,

First off, I like your chart. I like the way you number the additions
such as Loch.


I know there was reason that Read got rid of the two forms of Utter in
his original alphabet. I think the reason was that no one could
distinguish between the two? I know that I would have a hard time in
many cases. However, I think you are suggesting that we use the
alternate form of Ado discriminately, only before Roar, for example?

I also like the ligature Error and I think I'll include that in my font.
Regarding which ligatures to include, that is something I have also
thought about. If we include Earth, why not the others? Reading the news
today in occurred to me that there are other words which contain two
vowels followed by Roar, but these combinations did not confuse me. I
guess it comes down to how confusing ceratain combinations are. As I get
more experienced reading QS, will I be able to sort out Ado Roar Ed with
the same ease I sort out other letters? I can't tell at this point.

Paul
